title.native: ダンジョンに出会いを求めるのは間違っているだろうか外伝 ソード・オラトリア
title.romaji: Dungeon ni Deai wo Motomeru no wa Machigatteiru Darou ka Gaiden: Sword Oratoria
title.english: Sword Oratoria: Is it Wrong to Try to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon? On the Side

description:
Contrary to what the adventures of Bell and the Goddess Hestia might imply, not everyone goes into the dungeon of Orario to pick up girls. The veterans of the Goddess Loki’s Familia have lots of reasons for risking life and limb facing the monsters and mayhem lurking within the deadly labyrinth’s multiple levels, but new member and mage Lefiya just wants to prove that she’s worthy to be on the same team as her hero, the famed sword princess Ais Wallenstein. As for Ais herself, she’s seeking something that no one else even suspects, and she may find it when trouble comes after her from the previously unreached 59th level!

(Source: Sentai Filmworks)
synonyms: Is It Wrong to Hope to Meet a Girl in a Dungeon? On the Side: Sword Oratoria

tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Medieval
tags.description: Partially or completely set in the Middle Ages or a Middle Ages-inspired setting. Commonly features elements such as European castles and knights.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fujinoomori)

Fujino Oomori is a Japanese author most known for writing the [Danmachi](https://anilist.co/manga/85162/Is-It-Wrong-to-Try-to-Pick-Up-Girls-in-a-Dungeon/) light novel series. 

In early 2013, [Danmachi](https://anilist.co/manga/85162/Is-It-Wrong-to-Try-to-Pick-Up-Girls-in-a-Dungeon/) was submitted to the 4th GA Bunko Award, where it won and received an offer to have it published by Bunko.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/YooheySuzuki) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鈴木洋平_(アニメ演出家))

Youhei Suzuki is a director and former director of photography formerly working for [J.C.Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/JC-Staff). Currently freelance.

Not to be confused with the producer of the same name Youhei Suzuki (鈴木洋平).
Keiji Inai is a Japanese composer and arranger affiliated with the music production company IMAGINE.

Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/), where he is one of the studio's leading animators. His drawing corrections as animation director are known for his advanced drawing skills. Additionally, he is occasionally entrusted with powerful character acting and action sequences.

__Height:__ 157 cm
__Agency:__ Office Osawa

[Website](http://whv-amusic.com/iguchiyuka/index.html) | [Profile](http://osawa-inc.co.jp/women/iguchiyuka/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yukachiofficial) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/ooo31_iguchiyuka_31ooo/) | [Anison](http://anison.info/data/person/15320.html) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yuka_Iguchi) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%BA%95%E5%8F%A3%E8%A3%95%E9%A6%99) | [Youtube](https://youtube.com/@officialyoutubechannel3974?si=9AjlJ6Ujj2Vw1CiU)

__Non-anime roles:__
- Liter - Goddess of Victory: Nikke (VG)
- Otaru Rio - Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu: Cosplay, Hajimemashita (VN)
- 37 - Reverse: 1999 (VG)
- Koleda Belobog - Zenless Zone Zero (VG)

An art director who worked for Kobayashi Productions, but left together with [Hiromasa Ogura](https://anilist.co/staff/105312/) and Hiroshi Oono to establish Studio Fuga in March 3, 1983. He stayed until 1997, when he left to establish Moonflower, where he also acts as representative director.
In March 2010, she graduated from Tokyo Animation College.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/明田川仁)

Affiliated with Magic Capsule, a recording studio led by his father [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/松倉友二)

Affiliated with [J.C. Staff](https://anilist.co/studio/7/) since 1992, where he currently serves as the Executive Officer and General Manager of Production Headquarters. Also the representative director of Jam Creation.
